words.def: A passenger train of 56-foot steel-panelled carriages replacing 'Silver Fern' railcars on the North Island Main Trunk when they were unavailable
words.name: Blue Fern

words.def: ADK class on the Auckland suburban network
words.name: Blue Rattlers

words.def: Three NZR RM class 88 seater railcars renovated for a fast service between Hamilton and Auckland[1][2]
words.name: Blue Streaks

words.def: Yellow and black Tranz Rail livery. Introduced on DC 4323 in 2001 after the Makihi collision, and officially named 'Hi-Viz'. Originally all locos were to have the Tranz Rail winged logo, but most carried 'TR' block letters on the long hood and several locos did not carry any branding (No Name).
words.name: Bumble-Bee

words.def: WW class locomotives before rebuilding[citation needed]
words.name: Bobtail

words.def: Passenger carriage with a guard's compartment at one end, classes AF (wooden body) and AL (steel body). Originally built to relieve a shortage of guard's vans and used on rural branch lines in place of a separate carriage and guard's van, the later AL carvans were used in suburban service only.
words.name: Carvan

words.def: New Zealand Rail/Tranz Rail blue, yellow and grey livery used from 1990 to 2001. Originally NZ Rail used a darker blue, which was changed to a lighter tone by Tranz Rail.
words.name: Cato Blue

words.def: 1970s orange and yellow livery used on DX class[3]
words.name: Clockwork Orange

words.def: Coal train, particularly from Rapahoe and Ngakawau on the West Coast to Lyttelton. Also Genesis Energy coal trains between Mount Manganui and Weavers Crossing (these trains ceased running in 2012), but not for coal trains on the Rotowaro Industrial Branch.
words.name: Coalies

words.def: Auckland SX carriage set[citation needed]
words.name: Concrete Mixer

words.def: Toll Rail yellow and aquamarine livery.[4] First applied to DX 5379 for the launch of Toll Rail at Southdown in 2004, the last locomotive was to have been DXB 5143 but this unit was never painted in the complete livery.[original research?]
words.name: Corn-cob

words.def: A restored Wellington EMU set including DM 556[5]
words.name: Cyclops

words.def: DX class locomotives[citation needed]
words.name: Dixies

words.def: NZR RM class 88 seater railcars[6]
words.name: Drewrys

words.def: Northern Explorer
words.name: Dora the Explorer

words.def: Multiple locomotives coupled facing forward[citation needed]
words.name: Elephant style

words.def: N and M class steam locomotives coupled together. 'En, an abbreviation of 'hen', refers to the larger N class locomotive, and chicken refers to its underpowered M class assistant.[7]
words.name: 'En and chicken

words.def: The passenger train between Washdyke Junction and Fairlie along the Fairlie Branch. Also AB 699 on the Pleasant Point Railway, which runs along part of the old branch line.
words.name: Fairlie Flyer

words.def: NZR RM class 88 seater railcars[1]
words.name: Fiats

words.def: Matangi FP/FT class EMU 4472—so named as it shares its number with the LNER Class A3 steam locomotive 4472 Flying Scotsman
words.name: Flying Matangi

words.def: A simplified version of the Fruit Salad livery, with the grey replaced with red. Applied to members of the DC, DF, DSC, and TR class locomotives in the 1980s as a cheaper alternative to the full Fruit Salad livery.
words.name: Flying Tomato

words.def: NZR red and grey livery with yellow highlights, also known as International Orange[4]
words.name: Fruit Salad

words.def: A railfan—particularly one whose enthusiasm appears excessive[8]
words.name: Foamer

words.def: 88 seater railcars converted to carriages for locomotive haulage, from their green livery[2]
words.name: Grass Grubs

words.def: The Onerahi Branch's 323-metre-long bridge across the harbour in Whangarei, because of the large number of gulls that roosted there. The branch closed in 1933 and the bridge no longer exists.[9]
words.name: Gull Roost

words.def: The Johnsonville Line out of Wellington, or the steep section of the North Auckland Line between Newmarket and Remuera in Auckland. See Over the hill.[citation needed]
words.name: The Hill

words.def: FS class steam heating vans used to warm the carriages of passenger trains following the withdrawal of steam traction in 1968 (North Island) and 1971 (South Island)[3]
words.name: Hot water bottles

words.def: The L, LA, LB, and LC wagons—so called for their high metal (LA, LC) or wooden (L, LB) sides
words.name: Highsider

words.def: A livery of yellow, orange-red and grey, more popularly known as Fruit Salad[10]
words.name: International Orange

words.def: A track inspection vehicle[11]
words.name: Jigger

words.def: The section of the Midland Line between Springfield and Arthur's Pass famous for the use of KB class steam locomotives between 1939 and 1968[12]
words.name: KB country

words.def: Heritage passenger train instituted in 1972 using steam locomotives AB 778 and AB 795, originally between Lumsden and Kingston and later truncated to the 14 km between Fairlight and Kingston
words.name: Kingston Flyer

words.def: Former road and rail bridge on the now-closed portion of the Ross Branch south of Hokitika—named for the loud rattling its planks made[13]
words.name: Longest xylophone in the world

words.def: The M, MA, MB, MC, and MCC wagons, so called for their low sides. These wagons had lower sides than the L-series 'highsider' wagons, and were often used for loads that could not fit into a highsider or did not warrant the use of one.
words.name: Lowsiders

words.def: Locomotive on a bush tramway. Abbreviation of the term 'locomotive', but shortened by bush workers and adopted by railway enthusiasts.
words.name: Lokey

words.def: FT/FT class electric multiple unit used on the Wellington suburban network, chosen in 2008 in a public competition run by the Greater Wellington Regional Council, and comes from the Māori word matangi, meaning wind or breeze (in reference to Wellington's windy reputation)
words.name: Matangi

words.def: Livery on Auckland rolling stock operated by Transdev Auckland[citation needed]
words.name: MAXX Blue

words.def: Livery used in the 1920s and 1990s on passenger carriages, DM/D class electric multiple units and some other rolling stock. It was first trialled on the carriages of the Parnassus Express, the predecessor of the Picton Express. Its name derives from the London, Midland and Scottish Railway, from whom the colour was originally sourced.[14]
words.name: Midland Red

words.def: Several Tranz Rail locomotives received the 'Bumble Bee' paint scheme without any signwriting on the long hood. Mostly applied to members of the DC and DX classes.
words.name: No Name

words.def: DM/D class electric multiple units in their traditional red livery[15]
words.name: Old reds

words.def: The southern approach to Auckland from the North Island Main Trunk Railway at Westfield via the North Auckland Line and Newmarket Line. See The Hill.[citation needed]
words.name: Over the hill

words.def: E 66, nicknamed after its designer, G. A. Pearson, as it did not fulfill his ambitions[16]
words.name: Pearson's Dream

words.def: 1. Ford Model T railcars RM 4 and RM 5
words.name: Pie Cart

words.def: DXR class locomotive 8007 and 8022[citation needed]
words.name: The Pig

words.def: The DM 216 set, stored at Hutt Workshops out of service prior to its return to service in late 2008 or early 2009
words.name: The Phoenix

words.def: DAR 517[citation needed]
words.name: Pig Dog

words.def: New cabs fitted to ten of the DG class locomotives starting with DG 761 (TMS DG 2111) in late 1979 and ending in 1980
words.name: Pimple face

words.def: 1970s orange and yellow DX class livery[citation needed]
words.name: Popsicle

words.def: M class—named for their lack of pulling power in comparison to other classes[7]
words.name: Pullet

words.def: The Main South Line near Rakaia, where steam-hauled passenger express trains attained high speeds[17]
words.name: The racetrack

words.def: The Otira Tunnel, or the Karangahake tunnel on the East Coast Main Trunk Railway's former Waihi route[citation needed]
words.name: Rat hole or The Hole

words.def: Three-car DM/D class Tranz Metro Wellington units[citation needed]
words.name: Red Sets

words.def: A Leyland Cub car converted to run on rails for inspection use by the Railways Department General Manager Garnet Hercules Mackley in 1933. It was converted for uses associated with electrified lines in 1941, and after spending a few years in the Hutt Valley, it was transferred to Otira and remained there until the Otira Tunnel was de-electrified in 1997. It is now owned by the Ferrymead Railway.[18]
words.name: Red Terror

words.def: Wairarapa railcars, derived from the fact they were built to operate on the Rimutaka Incline[citation needed]
words.name: Rimutaka railcars

words.def: The Z class bogie vans, so called as they could be unloaded (supposedly) onto the roadside. Often used for parcels traffic, especially by Railfreight, and as luggage vans on express passenger trains, for which they were fitted with x-25330 'Timken' bogies to run at 80 km/h.
words.name: Roadsiders

words.def: ED electric locomotive 101, so called because of the three stripes on the body[19]
words.name: The Sergeant

words.def: Toll-liveried locomotive. Derived from Skippy the Bush Kangaroo, as Toll is an Australian company.[citation needed]
words.name: Skippy

words.def: The refurbished Ganz Mavag EMU EM 1373
words.name: Super Ganz

words.def: Wairarapa railcars[20]
words.name: Tin Hares

words.def: New Zealand EF class locomotives, because of their toaster-like appearance[citation needed]
words.name: Toasters

words.def: The preserved TR class locomotive[21]
words.name: Tonka Toy

words.def: 1970s orange and yellow livery; used on the DX class[22]
words.name: Tropical

words.def: DBR class Wellington-based locomotives 1200 and 1267, commonly paired for purposes such as banking south of Paekakariki. Because of this nickname, paired DBRs in Auckland are occasionally referred to as "non-identical twins", depending on their liveries.[23]
words.name: The Twins

words.def: NZR RM class 88 seater railcars[1]
words.name: Twinsets

words.def: Electric multiple units[citation needed]
words.name: Units

words.def: Track-inspection jigger[citation needed]
words.name: Velocipede

words.def: Tank car filled with water, used behind preserved steam locomotives[citation needed]
words.name: Water bottle
